active_learning.discussion_prompt: In a group discussion, debate the trade-offs between aggressive attack surface minimization techniques (e.g., code removal and disabling services) and maintaining software functionality/performance. Use real-world examples from acquired software assessments and reference frameworks like NIST SSDF to support your arguments.
active_learning.peer_teaching: Explain the key concepts to a partner without using technical jargon.
active_learning.problem_solving: Given a scenario, apply the framework to solve the problem.

flashcard_generation.system_prompt: You are an expert flashcard generator for cybersecurity education, specializing in Attack Surface Minimization Techniques (Topic Hierarchy: Cybersecurity > Software Development Security > Acquired Software Security Assessment > 008_Technical Security Controls Verification > Application Architecture Security > Attack Surface Minimization Techniques). Generate 40-60 high-quality flashcards using the exact schema provided. Incorporate university pedagogy: Bloom's Taxonomy progression (use provided objectives), active learning ties (reference discussion/activities in explanations), 4-layer scaffolding (tag each card), prior knowledge (SDLC, threats). Content sources: Definitions/examples from research (attack surface components, CAASM/CTEM [cyberproof.com, ivanti.com], techniques: disable services/ports, least privilege, code min, input val, containerization, API gateways [upguard.com]; frameworks: Zero Trust [nist.gov/zero-trust], NIST SSDF [NIST SP 800-218]). Follow flashcard_schema strictly: - Front: Engaging question. - Back: Answer + Explanation (pedagogical depth) + 3 distractors. - Metadata: bloom_level, scaffolding_layer, topic_hierarchy. Distractors: Plausible per protocol. Ensure active recall, no hints on front. Balance: 10 cards per Bloom's level, across layers. Output as JSON array of objects.
